titlestmt.titleproper: Henry Luce Foundation records, Record Group 4, Accession 2017:060
A Guide to the Henry Luce Foundation records, Record Group 4, Accession 2017:060 FA1442

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-09-14 00:21:15 -0400.

did.unittitle: Henry Luce Foundation records, Record Group 4, Accession 2017:060

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Henry Luce Foundation was established by Henry R. Luce in 1936. As a New York-based nonprofit organization, the Luce Foundation awards grants in American Art, Asian studies, Higher Education, Theology, and supports the Clare Boothe Luce Program for women in science, mathematics, and engineering.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by the Henry Luce Foundation in 2017.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC holds legal title. The Henry Luce Foundation retains all applicable intellectual property rights in so far as it holds them.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Henry Luce Foundation records (Record Group 4) are arranged as follows:
Series 2: American Art Conservation Initiative Files, 2006-2014
Series 3: Luce Fund for Southeast Asian Studies, 1982-2005
Series 4: Luce Fund for Chinese Scholars, 1980-2005

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Henry Luce Foundation records (Record Group 4) contain grant files and information on projects supported by the American Art Conservation Initiative, Luce Fund for Southeast Asian Studies, and Luce Fund for Chinese Scholars.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The American Art Conservation Initiative was a one-year program which funded the conservation of art in United States museums. These grants covered the cost of ongoing conservation treatments, such as exhibition preparation, stabilization, and framing. Eligible media included paintings, sculptures, drawings, prints, decorative arts, textiles, and photography.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by institution.

Luce Fund for Southeast Asian Studies

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Luce Fund for Southeast Asian Studies was designed to enhance the quality of Southeast Asian studies at both the graduate and the undergraduate levels at American Universities. It was a competitive grant program for universities that have made significant commitments to the field of Southeast Asian studies. Grants were awarded for faculty development, library development, student fellowships, public education, and other programs that were considered beneficial to the growth of the field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Luce Fund for Southeast Asian Studies series contains general information about the initiative including program guidelines, grants, and surveys. This series also includes information about each of the nine institutions that were invited to participate in the program: Cornell University, Northern Illinois University, Northwest Regional Consortium for Southeast Asian Studies (Universities of Oregon and Washington), Ohio University, University of California (Berkeley), University of Hawaii, University of Michigan, University of Wisconsin (Madison), and Yale University.

Luce Fund for Chinese Scholars

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Luce Fund for Chinese Scholars was created to enhance the study of China in major American academic centers and encourage interaction between Chinese and American scholars. Each participating university was eligible to receive support for one scholar-in-residence from China for each academic year. The grants awarded were not competitive in nature, but were based on nominations from the universities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: General program information can be found at the beginning of the series. Individual grant files can be found within university-specific sub-series.

did.unittitle: Board Proposal for the Luce Fund for Chinese Scholars
Evaluations

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Closed -- contains peer review materials.
